content.description: Easy climbing with face holds gets you past the wide rotten section at the base, then the cliff steepens and the crack shrinks to hand and fist sizes on rough rock. Belay with gear on a ledge. To descend scramble down north (climber's left) from the top of the crack at the ledge or take the ledge all the way to the right end and up a short crack to a shoulder of South Breezeway Dome, then continue down ledges and ramps to the southern toe of the dome.
content.location: On the west face of South Breezeway Dome towards the north end.

climbs.name: The Jim-n-I
climbs.fa: First Known Ascent Joel "Scurve Dog" Adams, Jim "Frodo" Lybarger, early 2000

content.description:
Climb the right leaning crack for 20’ climb around a small bulge and walk 15’ and continue the right leaning crack for 30’ that flares towards the top.

 Decent: walk off climbers left down gully to 5th class chimney towards the base
content.location: From camp 4 walk towards south breezeway dome, about 200yds to the left of hawk rock is the base of the route.

climbs.name: Guillotine Crack
climbs.fa: Unknown, FRA Dan Briley, Joel Adams

content.description: Climb a fingers to hand-sized left leaning crack to detached looking block that parallels a small dyke on the left. Stand onto the block, leaving the crack to finish with face moves on the dyke where it crosses to the right side. Belay with gear across the gully at the top. Walk off descent.
content.location: The rightmost route on the west side at the base of the southern crest of the dome.

content.description: Climb nice patina coated face moves to a dyke passing a couple bolts. Continue on the dyke past a ledge and up the last section where the rock has split forming a crack next to the dyke. Belay with two bolts and descend the gully behind and left of the climb.
content.location: Just left of the center on the east side. Start from the ground behind some scrub oak.

content.description: A short, sweet, slightly past vertical crack formed by a detached toe of the dome. Starts with hands and gets wider from there. Two bolts serve for the belay for this climb and the climb on the backside of this crack. Don't rap as the bolts are just for belaying and far from the edge. Descend by going north a few feet, hop over to the west side and down the stepped narrow ledge.
content.location: On the south crest of the dome halfway up on the east side. Go all the way to the south end of the dome and 3rd class back north along the crest and ledges.

content.description: This climb is the back half of Brusk. A vertical crack that starts with fists and gets wider towards the top. Belay with two bolts. Descend by going north a few feet, hop over to the west side and down the stepped narrow ledge.
content.location: On the south crest of the dome halfway up on the west side. Go all the way to the south end of the dome and 3rd class back north along the crest and ledges.

climbs.name: Breezeway
climbs.fa: Paul Van Betten, Sal Mamusia, Robert Conz, Shelby Shelton

content.description: Climb the face past four bolts supplemented by gear to a two bolt anchor below a sloping ledge under a roof.
content.location: At the west end of the Breezeway just before it opens up on the north face of South Breezeway Dome.

content.description: A short arching tips crack above an overhang. Start on the bottom left. Belay with gear, walk off descent.
content.location: At the bottom of North Breezeway Dome in a small gully, left of center on the east face.

climbs.name: Blood, Sweat, and Gear
climbs.fa: Dan Briley, Cassondra Long, Joel Adams- first known ascent

content.description: The left of two right leaning parallel cracks with a slight step in the middle. Belay with gear on a large ledge, scramble down the south ridge to descend.
content.protection: Set of stoppers, cams- micro to 4”, one piece in the 12” range for the lower section.
content.location: In the center of the east face, about two thirds the way up.

content.description: South Breezeway Dome is the southern most of the three big domes in the main camping area. North and South Breezeway Domes get there name from The Breezeway, a narrow east-west scrub oak-filled corridor that sits between them. The summit can be gained by class 3 scrambling from the south to a ledge on the east, below the summit cap, then doing an easy boulder move to the top.
